keyTakeAways: Erik and Lyle Menendez were resentenced to 50 years to life in prison by Judge Michael Jesic, making them eligible for parole for the first time since their 1989 murder convictions.
The brothers took full responsibility for the killings, citing years of childhood sexual abuse and self-defense as justification, and emphasized remorse and rehabilitation.
Family members and prison staff testified to the brothers' remorse, rehabilitation, and efforts to improve prison life, including Lyle's beautification program and Erik's support groups.
The current Los Angeles County District Attorney, Nathan Hochman, opposes resentencing, citing fabricated abuse claims and a moderate risk of recidivism based on risk assessments.

The brothers are seeking both parole through the state board and gubernatorial clemency, as well as a new trial via habeas corpus, with new evidence including a 1988 letter from Erik referencing abuse.
Governor Gavin Newsom has the power to commute sentences or deny parole and has not yet acted, with prior precedent in denying Sirhan Sirhan's parole.
The decision marks a significant shift in the legal and public perception of the case, opening the door to potential release after 35 years in prison.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A California judge has resentenced Erik and Lyle Menendez to 50 years to life for the 1989 murders of their parents, making them eligible for parole for the first time since their conviction. While the judge acknowledged the horror of the crime and praised the brothers' demonstrated remorse, rehabilitation, and contributions in prison — including Lyle's beautification program and Erik's support groups — he did not recommend release, stating that parole should be considered in the future. The brothers, who have maintained claims of self-defense due to years of childhood abuse, are now seeking parole through the state board and potential clemency from Governor Gavin Newsom. The Los Angeles County District Attorney Nathan Hochman opposes the resentencing, citing fabricated abuse claims and a moderate risk of recidivism. The parole board is set to hear their case on June 13, and Newsom has 120 days to decide whether to grant or deny parole. The decision marks a significant shift in the legal narrative of the case, opening a path to potential release after 35 years in prison, though it remains subject to further review and executive discretion.
title: Erik and Lyle Menendez Resentenced to 50 Years to Life, Opening Door for Possible Parole, Judge Rules
